sp.p: O fie! the intolerable Preſumption of Fellows! Had not you better make the Campaign in Flanders than in Pelmel and at the Wells and Bath?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Pox, I play'd away my Equipage-Mony at Piquet, and that damn'd Baſſette—But tell me, dear Creature, how long muſt I ſtill ſigh in vain for you?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Exceeding Pretty, as I'm a Chriſtian! Why, you have not begun yet, that I know of.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: What a Pox, do you reckon this Viſit nothing?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: When you can be conſtant, perhaps I may think you deſerve Encouragement.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: 's Death, at that rate I might wait long enough, Child! I find I muſt ſtorm the Out-works, in order to a General Aſſault—Thus then I inveſt the Town, my fair Enemy.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis Time to call for Relief—Who's there? Unkle! What were you aſleep?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: You may ſwear it, or how▪ cou'd I have been ſo long without talking? Pox, this Wine is got into my Head! Well, what's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: When a Woman begins to cry out, you may believe the Jeſt is over.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Why, 'twas but juſt going to begin.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: I find we've jeſted too long, I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: I fear I have, for I muſt follow you in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Jeſt or Earneſt, 'tis all one to Sam: If he's caught let him take it for his Pains: They ſay there's no fooling with the Devil, but I fancy that Saying will hardly hold good of Women, Egad.

lg.l: Bewitching Woman's a reſiſtleſs Evil,
The Devil fools us, but ſhe'd fool the Devil.

div.stage: Enter Railmore, ſeemingly drunk, Sir Tope, and Ilbred, with his Sleeves tuck'd up, as from the Club

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Nay, ſince you've got your Load elſewhere, and won't ſtay, prethee tell us here, in good ſober Senſe?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Then, in no ſober Senſe, if this Nephew of thine has her, he'll be a Cuckold; 'twou'd be a Shame if he were not, he has the beſt Qualifications for't, and wants that to be in the Faſhion.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Heighday! I'll warrant you then, your Londoners have brought up that Faſhion, theſe dead Times, for want of Trade; a Cuckold!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Ay, or a Husband, that's all one, I think: Look you, you Put, I'll ſtand to what I ſay. reeling, flings down a Letter, the Squire takes it up Canſt thou read Squire? Here's a Letter, I took it up by Chance; from whom and to whom d'you think it is, hah?

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Ods me, 'tis from Francelia! 'Tis the ſame Hand as mine: Let ſee— he reads ſcurvily My dear Lord, tho your Francelia is condemned to marry a Fool—(that's me) you may help her to revenge on him the Wrong that's done you—In ſpight of all ſlaviſh Bonds, ſhe vows to be my Lord Lovewel's while ſhe is Francelia—Ods bob • ! who'd ha' thought it?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: May the Curſe of ſmall Beer, in an Evening light on me, if I don't go and rattle her to ſome Tune anon!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hang her, Man! ne're go to her, 'twill ſpight her more: Beſides, my Lord is a bloody-minded Devil, he makes no more of killing a Man than a Doctor of Phyſic does.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Odſooks, 'tis all a Caſe, I'll go—but I'll conſider on't firſt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Odsbobs, Sirs, why d'you leave us ſo? you're Three Bumpers behind-hand. There's Juſtice Dolt ſwears at you like any Carrier in a Slough. Come, Maſter of mine, come in; don't ſtand here holding of a Parley.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Not I; I am not ſuch a Sot; I have enough: I'd as ſoon go to a County-Feaſt, or a Punning Club at London.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Why, there are not ſo many Fools here as at London, Friend of mine!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: There are fewer Fools here indeed, becauſe there are fewer People.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Odsbobs, that Shan't ſerve turn, you ſhall drink with us for all that.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I'd ſooner go back to London among the Rable for, there tolerable Wine at leaſt is had, in good Rooms, if not in good Company; but here your Room is wretched, your Liquor bad, and your Company abominable; and ſo farewel, Brother Sots.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Well, go thy waies, Nutmeggrater! what pity 'tis, Major Buff, that ſuch a tart witty Knave can't drink!

div.stage: Enter Plot, dreſt like a Gipſie. Two or Three Gipſies.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I tell you your Fortune, you pretty Man; you live well, you be good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What Vermin ha'we here? Gipſies! nay then mind your Pockets.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: An angry one, an angry one!

sp.speaker: Il,
sp.p: Gad, Unkle, they ſhall tell me my Fortune, for all that, but I'll mind 'em.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Ay, preſently; croſs you my Hand with one piece of Silver, I tell you all then.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Here 'tis, old Egypt!

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Let me ſee your Head! Oh the good ſtrong Head, fit for the Country Juſtice!

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: What! tell a Man's Fortune by his Head?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Yes, we tell the Lawyer the Fortune by both the Hands, the pretty Woman by the Eye, the Lover by the long Noſe, the Drunkard by the Copper-Noſe, the Dancing-Maſter by the Foot, the Taylor by the Calves of the Leg, the Alderman by the Forehead, and you by the whole Head together.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Why, what doſt thou take me for then?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Let ſee! You no be the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: How! no Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: No, but you be the Squire.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Oh ho! well, I'll try your Skill e'Faith. Come, when wan't I well laſt, hah?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: You have not been well lately.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Now thou'rt a greater Lyar than Patridge's Almanack.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: No, I ben't, I ſee by your Hand that 'twas—the Itch.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: The Itch! Thou lyeſt like the Devil's Tooth-Drawer.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I mean the Itch of Love. You be troubled with it yet. You love the very fine Woman, but you be jealous of her, and will not have her for fear—

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Hum! if thou canſt but tell me how old I am, I'll believe thou knoweſt whether ſhe wou'd be honeſt or no.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Let me ſee your Mouth! How old was you when your Father Dy'd?

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Sixteen.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Don't ſtir! and 'tis now ſince he dy'd.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Five Years.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p:
Look you, I find that if you marry this Woman
that you deſign to court to Day, you be one very great Cuckold by ſome great Perſon; but if you not go to her, and take no notice at all, you ſoon will have another more to your Mind, with great deal Mony; but this is not to bring you one Croſs: And for a Proof of this, I will tell you your Age as you ask me—You be—you be—juſt One and twenty, as I find by your Mouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: ſtops Plot, Ilbred and Major Buff run after the

sp.speaker: Gipſies.
sp.p: The Gipſies ſteal off, having first pick'd Ilbred's Pockets and Sir Topewel's.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Odſooks, the Gipſies ha' pick'd my Pocket—ſtop 'em, I have one faſt—Ah Rogues! You tell Fortunes, but cou'd not tell your own. You ſhall be truſt up next Aſſizes, hang'd in Chains, and ſhewn for a right Egyptian Mummy.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Good Sir, hear me! As I'm an honeſt Man, 'twas not I pickt your Pocket; beſides, I'm no Gypſie, an't pleaſe you. Oh! Good your Worſhip, let me go; I'll diſcover a Plot to you.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: A Plot! no more Plots, we've had too many already.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: 'Tis a Plot againſt Squire Ilbred to fool him out of his Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Fool me! The beſt Lord in the Land make a Fool of me, I won't marry.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: The Devil helps th • ſe ſame Gypſies, they were too nimble for us.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Nay, now I ſmell a Rat; well, ſpeak Truth and thou ſhalt go free.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p:
I am my Lord Lovewel's Man, Sir, ſet on by Mr. Railmore, who e'en now, pretending to be drunk, got you out, and kept you a talking till he ſaw us, to give me an Opportunity to make the Squire believe he'll be a Cuckold if he marries Mrs. Francelia: He was to
ſhew you a Letter; that's a ſham-one, upon my Honour▪ as well as that the Squire receiv'd.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Why, this was no Sham-Plot tho; this was a Plot indeed: Well, I ſet thee free for this Diſcovery; but canſt thou not tell me more?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I ſhall be turn'd away, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Come, fear not; we'll provide for thee.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Well, you are ſuch good natur'd Gentlemen that it goes againſt my Heart to ſee you deceiv'd. I will tell you, whatever comes on't.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: I'll reward thee to thy own Content; believe me, I am no Courtier.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: You muſt know, my Lord is to marry Mrs. Francelia very privately to Night; not that ſhe hates the Squire, but becauſe my Lord is a Lord, I think: I know no other Reaſon; for I know ſome Women that have ſtaid Twelve Years for a Lord, and now wou'd be glad to take up with a Squire, or any thing. Now I fancy▪ I could put your Worſhip in a way to put his Noſe out of Joint, but—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Come, but me no Buts! ſerve him, and I'll do thy Buſineſs; thy Lord himſelf ſhan't live better than thou ſhalt. Couſin, give him ſome of the Broad Pieces thou haſt for a Taſte.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Odſme! they're all Gipſied away: My Pocket has been gutted already. Well, till anon, take this Ring, and that Tobacco Box.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Pray excuſe me, Sir; I hate to take any thing for doing good—won't this look like a Bribe?—Theſe real Gipſies, whom I got to come with me▪ could not forbear ſtealing—Your Worſhip's moſt humble Servant—Well, I believe I might eaſily convey you, when 'tis dark, into the Room by the Hall, where my Lord intends to be married to your Miſtreſs, unknown to any Body but my ſelf and the Chaplain; there won't be ſo much as a Light, and they are to whiſper all the while, for fear Sir Thomas ſhould come and ſpoil all.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: O rare! We'll come, we'll come.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: 'Twill be dark about an Hour hence, Sir, I'll wait for you near the Hall, but then you muſt be very private: Your Worſhip's moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Now, Lads, let's go Drink!

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Here they are!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: A Word with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Make haſte then, for we're a dry.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I hear, you raiſe your Pretences to a Lady, whom I Court with her Father's Conſent.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Ay, and he ſhall Wed her, and Bed her with my Conſent, and her Father's Conſent. Do you come to be Invited to the Wedding?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: No, we come to forbid the Ba • es, Sir, and to deſire you to deſiſt.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: But what if I wont, Sir?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Then I muſt try to make you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: So, here's like to be othergueſs fighting than we have on our Muſter-Days: I'll go get a Reinforcement, and then boldly march up—in the Reer of it.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: You wear a Sword, Sir!

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis but a Hanger neither. Look you, I a'n't for Single Rapier; we ſcorn your little Spit-frog Play: That's a French Trick: But for Wreſtling, Cudgels, or good downright Backſword ſlaſhing, may haps I won't turn my Back to the beſt Maſter of the Science in the County.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Why, that's only fit for Butchers and Hedge-Fencers, to fight ſham Prizes before a Bear-Garden Rabble.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: I'll Drink with you for her then, and Unkle will be my Second.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Sir, if you wou'd ſhow yourſelf a Gentleman, get a Sword and—

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: My Bay Gelding ſhall run▪ with the beſt Horſe in your Stable for her, three Heats, Weight him and Inch him—Methinks I ſhou'd not want Courage, I drink Stout and Cherry-Brandy • 'ry Day.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Odsſooks, ſay no more, Cuz, Lug out, we'll make their hollow Blades fly in ſhatters about their Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir? Then have at yours.

div.stage: They draw and fight: Sir Top▪ and▪ Ilb▪ give way till the Clowns come, then they come forward, and are, by a Miſtake, knock'd down by their Party, and crawl off: The Clowns are beaten off the Stage.
Enter Humphrey and two Clowns with Flails and Quarterſtaffs, Major Buff behind 'em, Hallowing, and Parſon Humdrum while they are fighting.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Odsnigs, Thraſh 'em thick and threefold; have among you blind Harpers, fall Back fall Edge.

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Gentlemen, Pax▪ eſt bona res, ſays a Learned Father; Peace is a good Thing: Knock 'em down, Humphrey, Peace is a good Thing: Knock 'em down, Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Come, my Lord, we've got the Day, as moſt Generals do, by Chance▪ You'll ſcarce be made one, tho' we ſhou'd win t'other Battle; ſo, let's away to think of other means to defeat your Rival effectually; for, after all, he's but the more dangerous for being a Blockhead.

div.stage: Enter Lady Single; with a Book in her Hand; her Woman at a Diſtance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Oh, why do we complain we live too little! When ev'n the Wiſe want ſomething more than Wiſdom to fill up the long uſeleſs Blanks of Life! Tir'd by our ſelves, with others ſoon uneaſie, a while with Books we trifle Time away; but ev'n that ſolitary Pleaſure grows inſipid, and often wakes the Cares it ſhould beguile; whereas, he that knows nothing, doubts of nothing! So, Cowley, thou ſay'ſt right, and Life is an incurable Diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, if I am ſo ſelfiſh as to break in upon your Meditations! Hearing that my Lord and Mr. Airy were gone to the Club, I was walking this way till they▪ come back; for I gueſs they'll hardly be able to ſtay there longer than I did: Well, I ſhould be ſicker yet of the Country than of London, were there no better Society there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You'll find that ſcarce enough, I doubt, Mr. Railmore.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, yet ſome few Men and Women of Sence, I hope will make me amends.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Women here! Why, Romances, Chaplains and Simplicity, or rather Ruſticity, ſpoil more of 'em for Converſation, than Affectation does at London.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Nay, as for Simplicity, Madam, 'tis a Stranger to this Family at leaſt; if 'tis not one in ſo fair a Lady as your ſelf to be an Enemy to Man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not while Man is ſuch an Enemy to Woman.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: 'Tis pity you're ſo prejudic'd againſt us all; for ſome one might have Lov'd you on the Square, and thus have prevented that Rough, Scornful, Melancholick Air that frightens away the Love your Face and Sence attract.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, do you believe Love makes us more agreeable▪ Mr. Railmore?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Certainly, Madam, it wears away gently all our Native Roughneſs, gives a pleaſing Turn to our Expreſſions, a taking Air to our Perſon, and winning Graces to all our Actions; nay, I'll maintain it makes a Woman more Beautiful.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: More Beautiful! Nay, now I doubt you are more a Diſſember than I thought you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Why, Madam, as I ſpeak to a Woman of Sence, I can prove my Aſſertion: Pray is not the Face the Mirror of the Mind?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Without doubt it ſhould be ſo.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Does not then a Mind given over to cold Indifference communicate a certain Lethargy to the Face, that makes ev'ry Feature lifeleſs and unactive, and ſpreads a chilling unlovely Air over the whole Perſon?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: This is ſomewhat likely, I think.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Now on the contrary, a ſingle Spark of Love happily kindled in a youthful Heart, makes the Imagination quicker, the Wit more free, the Converſation more lively, the Eyes more ſparkling, and diffuſes o'er the Face that ſprightly moving Je-ne-ſcay-quoy, whoſe Charms 'tis impoſſible to reſiſt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Since I was Born, I never was ſo ſtrangely tempted to make a Tryal of this.— Aſide.—But ſeriouſly do you believe, Mr. Railmore, I ſhould look more tolerably if I ſhew'd leſs Averſon to your Sex?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Give me leave to convince you now of what I ſaid; but firſt be pleas'd to let your Woman give us a Song that may divert you from more ſerious Thoughts:
Your Dreſs too ſhou'd be artfully looſe, and careleſly Genteel; for Love neglects us, when we neglect our ſelves.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, for once I'll humour you in your Frolick: Sing us a Song!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, what I am doing? I like this Woman ſtrangely, but then I— Aſide.—hate the Nuptial-Nooſe as much. She's vaſtly Rich too, and I have ſcarce enough left to Live. What ſhall I do? If I Court her in Earneſt, I may be made her Jeſt, and all the World's. Thus Love begins by Fooling, till we Fool our ſelves; and what is worſe, we know it, yet go on.

lg.head: A RONDEAU.
lg.l: MOrtals, learn your Lives to meaſure,
Not by length of Time, but Pleaſure.
Now the Hours invite comply;
While you idly pauſe, they fly:
Blest, while a brisk pace they keep,
But in Torment when they creep.
Mortals, learn your Lives to meaſure,
Not by length of Time, but Pleaſure.
Soon your Spring must have a Fall:
Loſing Youth, is loſing all.
Then you'll ask, but none will give,
And may linger, yet not Live.
Mortals, learn your Lives to meaſure,
Not by length of Time, but Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, Maſter, am I now as I ſhould be?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You only want ſeven or eight Patches: They are to Women what Shades are to Pictures, or Stars over the Face of Night; a Beauty's no more compleat without 'em, than a Beau is without Pouder.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fye, they ſhould be as ſcandalous now as Velvet-Scarfs, or Velvet-Faces thoſe greater Patches: Sempſtreſſes, Barkeepers, Chambermaids and City Beaux, wear 'em.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: There's no harm in a few for all that; but I wou'd not have you like my old Lady Tawdry, whoſe fat Face looks juſt like a Gammon of Bacon ſtuck over▪ with Cloves, with more Patches on than ſhe's Years old, over her double Mask of Hypocriſie and Paint.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, how d'you like me now?

div.stage: She puts on ſome Patches, and makes Sign to her Woman to leave her, and ſhe leaves 'em.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Why, you'll ſoon bid fair for a Place among the Firſt Rates; chiefly now there are ſo few! Well, be pleas'd to ſit, and do but remember to Hear me, Believe me, and Anſwer me ſincerely. I intend to ſpeak to you, as 'tis ſuppos'd a Perſon wou'd do, whoſe Wealth and Merit might embolden him to make his Addreſſes to your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I ſet little Value upon Wealth, true Merit affects me much more; ſo Mr. Railmore, pray ſpeak as of your ſelf, and do not perſonate another.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Since you are ſo kind, Madam, as to prevent my hopes, and give me leave to profeſs the Love I have for you, I'll wave all thoſe Hyperboles, ſo commonly laviſh'd in Declarations of Love, and all the Hell of Pain which whining Fools, and deſigning Knaves pretend to feel, and really deſerve.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: All exploded thread-bare Cant, to be caſt off, like dull Romances, and only us'd by Pedants and Abigails.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I'll neither meanly Cringe nor ſawcily Preſume; neither magnifie your Worth by Flattery, nor debaſe my own by affected Diſpraiſe, or Self-Commendation: No, Madam, the only Eloquence, I ought to uſe to perſwade a Woman of your▪ Sence, is my ſincerity in doing Juſtice to your Merit: Thus I only urge the Eſteem I have for you, to claim your Ladyſhip's.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: 'Tis the ſureſt way to gain it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And if I ever obtain that Bleſſing, you'll never find the leaſt Unevenneſs in my Temper, the leaſt Contradiction in my Sentiments, or Decay in my Affections.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Were this poſſible, Sir, I muſt own 'twou'd be as ſingular, as ſweet.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Can you wrong me ſo much as to doubt it, Madam?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: We eaſily doubt of what we wiſh.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Think more favourably of a Man whom you have always found to ſpeak his Thoughts, and who being tir'd with long Wandring, a • d ripe for a Retreat, wou'd fix a grateful Heart, and be for ever True.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sure you forget you are a Man, Mr. Railmore! What, cou'd you Love a Wife, none but a Wife, and that for ever too?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Yes, Madam, cou'd that▪ Wife reſemble you ſo much as to be thought your ſelf: But that's above my hopes: Yet our equal Averſion hitherto to Marriage, to Fools▪ Flattery, and the Hurry of the World, ſhows two Humours ſo ſuited to each other, that they would ſeem but one, if both were joyn'd: And as each of us at once wou'd Conquer, and be Conquer'd, ſuch an Union of two Marriage-Haters cou'd be but Honourable and Sweet to both. We'd pity wretched Couples, link'd by the poor Sympathy of Intereſt, or Frenzy; while you and I, claſp'd in each other's Arms, wou'd
think we two engroſs'd all the Delights they forfeit, and Life and Love can give—Oh do not turn that Lovely Face aſide; or I ſhall think you're made of Ice indeed, and hate my ſelf for being not like you.

div.stage: She turns aſide, and looks in her Glaſs, and ſighs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By Heaven! He has kept his Word: I Bluſh to think on't, yet almoſt wiſh he might be in Earneſt.— Aſide.—I Vow, Mr. Railmore, you act your Part ſo well, that Truth it ſelf cou'd ſcarce have mov'd me more.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: By Heav'n, Madam, 'tis real all; and to prove it with a Witneſs, I'll ſend for ſome living Form of Sanctity to confirm it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, are you then come to the End of Love already?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No, no, dear Madam, I wou'd only come to the Seal of it. Conſider if our Sexes Paſſion ends before yours; 'tis chiefly through your Coldneſs at firſt, and your Fondneſs at laſt. We ſet out too ſoon, or you too late; and you either Starve Love, or overload it ſo, that the poor Thing ſeldom holds out to its Journey's end: But you and I ſetting out together, our Loves ſhall keep pace with each other, and their Race, and that of Life be the ſame.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But will not the whole World laugh at us?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: The Thought on't moves me a little, I muſt confeſs: But what's the World, the Vile Mad World to us? Beſides we may be a while as private as you pleaſe, and Laugh at thoſe who vainly hope to Laugh at one of us.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, I muſt needs own you're an excellent Maſter, ſince you have in ſo little a Time made me look leſs diſagreeably, and almoſt perſwaded me, a Man may be worthy of being Lov'd. Cou'd I believe you ſuch——

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Oh! I am wild to convince you of it more feelingly. Let me ſeize that fair Hand, and bribe it with fond Kiſſes, to be a Pledge to mine of a Return. Ah! let me, let me in this ſweet, this wiſe Extravagance of Paſſion, kindly force you to come and make it lawful now.

lg.l: Too long in vain againſt your Heav'n you ſtrove:
The only Care that ſhould a Woman move
lg.stage: He draws her along half complying.
lg.l: Is to be fair, to be belov'd, and love.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE, a Room.
div.stage: Enter Kitty in Page's Clothes, and Frankly in Chambermaid's.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: WELL, you have made me put on Page's Clothes, but I can't put on Page's Aſſurance. I tremble, and have not power to go.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What! afraid to go and be married to the man you ſay you love?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: No, rather afraid my Siſter ſhould hinder it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's a grave Gentleman in black hard by, who'll ſoon put that out of her Power, and then you may eaſily get out in this Diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p:
Nay, I was forc'd to tell her a fair Story to get from her: ſhe believ'd me preſently, for, I thank Heaven, ſhe never could catch me in a Lye, and yet I tell I don't
know how many e'ery day: But what will ſhe ſay when ſhe finds I have deceiv'd her?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pſha, whom do we not deceive to be married? Think o' the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Well, let's go, I fancy I was not made to be a Nun.

div.stage: Enter Sir Tho. Gaymood, Sir Topewell, and Illbred.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I tell you I have taken care my Daughter ſhall entertain him as ſhe ought: I have injoyn'd her to think no more of my Lord Lovewel. But ſee! here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Daughter, you know what I ſaid to you: Make much of Squire Illbred for my ſake, more for his, and more ſtill for your own. Come, Sir Topewell.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Go go, get you gone, I muſt ſtay a little to hearten him up.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you be pleas'd to ſit, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Thank you, Madam, I am well as I am: I love to be in a ſtanding Poſture.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: What, won't you ſit by your Miſtreſs, man?

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Now I think on't, I don't much care if I do; nay, and lye by her too.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Mark that! heighboy! To Fran.—Say ſomething to her!

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: We've had a fine day to day.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But an odd one, Sir, in my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Tope.
sp.p: Speak to her, good Lad!

div.stage: To Ilbr. aſide, and Ilbred jogs him again angrily.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Why, the Roads are as dry as theſe Boards.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p:
Ay, and the dryer they are, the dryer they
make us: Wou'd I had a Bumper or two of that ▪Hock! Aſide. Speak to her, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what News d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, none that's good: A Friend of mine is importun'd to marry a man ſhe does not love.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Is that ſuch ill News? Why, 'tis as common in Marriage to hate at firſt, and then love, as 'tis to love at firſt and then hate. Coſen, to her! Odſooks thou'rt at leaſt a quart too low. When firſt I went a wooing, I made my ſelf half drunk, and then I ſpoke up as boldly as a Member that either ſcorns or wants a Penſion.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Well, when once we're got acquainted, I'll mend my Hand.—Pray, Madam, how old may you be?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You ſhou'd never ask a Woman her Age, Mr. Ilbred, leſt ſhe anſwer you falſe, or diſoblige herſelf.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Cry mercy, I meant no more harm than a man that cheapens a Horſe or a Mare does, when he asks how old 'tis: I ask'd, becauſe I fancy you and I are much of an age, and thus may the better be yoak'd together.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis not likeneſs of Age, but of Inclination, that makes the Yoke eaſie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: I've nothing to ſay as to that; but if Somebody loves Somebody, as well as Somebody loves Somebody, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What's that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Why then Somebody will have Somebody, or Nobody, inſpight of Every body.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis well if any body can underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Look you, that is, if you love him as well as he loves you, 'tis a March; tho' this ſame Lord we ſaw here thought to have huff'd him out of you, and forg'd a Letter as from you, to make us believe you'll Cuckold my Coſen, yet he dares venture on you, nay, and take you, tho' you had not a Smock to your Back.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Lord, contrive a Letter as from me.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Ay, that he did; his ſurly Companion ſhow'd it us. Well, what ſay you? Nothing? Well! I find there's one Woman in the World has not too much Tongue. Coſen, ſay as I tutor'd you.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, I an't us'd to make Love, and mayn't talk ſo much like a Courtier (never the worſe man for that) I am downright Dunſtable, I've for theſe many Months hoarded up——

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: A Barnful of good hearty Country Love for you.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Unkle, hold you your prating Tongue, will you; or rather get you gone; John the Butler, your old Pot-Companion wants you: I'm in now, man.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Then puſh it home, Boy. God b'w'ye.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: I fancy I can talk better now the old Sot my Uncle has left us. Faith and troth, I lov'd you this great while, and if you'll be rul'd by a Fool, e'en have me, I dare ſay you'll be Mother of many Children▪ What ſay you? Come, as the new Song has it, Here's my Heart, and here's my Hand too; all that's mine ſhall be thine, Body and Goods at thy Command too. Sings. Odsbobs, now I'm in, you ſhall ſee me jig it away: I've got Muſicianers juſt by: Soho Fidlers! play me a Leſſon; come, Roger a Coverly, a Jig, any thing, play your May-day Tune, Tom Crowder.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Now go about your buſineſs, and leave me to manage mine: O ſweet Miſtreſs Frances, I long to be at another ſort of Dancing with you; faith and troth I've lov'd you this great while.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'm afraid the Clown will prove as impudent at laſt as he was ſhamefac'd. A • ide—Sir, you ſurprize me with the News of your Love.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Odsbobs, is it a News to you? Why, I've been at Church, and what buſineſs could I have there but to ſee you, think you? I've hunted by you▪all▪ along to the ſame intent, and us'd to hollow in a Morning, to wake you, that you might know on't, thus, So-ho!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The noiſe was the only Inſtance of your Love that ever diſturb'd me to this day; but I'll beg another: 'Tis my firſt Requeſt, ſo I hope you'l not deny it.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Nay, to be ſure I muſt do as you'd ha' me, that you may do as I'd have you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Then, Sir, that firſt Requeſt is, That you would be ſo kind as to leave me, and think no more of me.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, I was told you'd be as ſhy as a high-metal'd Filly when ſhe's to be back'd firſt; but troth, you may kick and wince, and ſtand up an end, but I won't be thrown off the Saddle, I won't budge a Foot as long as my Name's Ilbred.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Now I think better on▪t I muſt humour you. A good Evening to you; but I'll be with you ſooner than you think.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sir, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: I'll be with you anon; I muſt go look after my Horſes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You have a mighty Aſcendant over this Gentleman, my Lord; he leaves the Room as ſoon as he ſees you.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: You have a greater over me, Madam; nothing▪ could make me leave you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But my Father, who ought to have the greateſt Aſcendant over me, commands me to leave you to entertain him.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: But my Rival is kinder than your Father, and leaves me to entertain you. Ah, Madam! while you ſtint me to bare Friendſhip, muſt he engroſs the Treaſure of your Love, which he wants Sence to value as he ought?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The leſs Sence a Man has▪ the more he prizes Things whoſe worth is only imaginary. And after all, my Lord, he gives me no ſmall Proof of his Eſteem, in offering to eaſe my Father of the Charge of my Perſon, without a Portion to ſupport that Charge. He uſes no ill means to obtain me; he did not cauſe a falſe immodeſt Letter, written as by me to himſelf, to be ſhown his Rival, to deter him from purſuing his Intentions.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: I do not know that he did ſo.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I ſay he did not, but I know who did.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Tell me who did, that I may puniſh him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He needs no other Puniſhment but Neglect. Farewel.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Going! What can this mean? Stay, Madam, explain your Riddle.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You, who did all this, need no Explanation.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: I! by all that's true, I know nothing of this, and bluſh to think you can ſuſpect me of it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: There's more than Suſpicion, I'm aſſur'd of it.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Hold, Madam, do not perſiſt in thinking me ſo baſe as to deny the Truth, or I ſhall ceaſe to think you what I thought you, and ſtrive to grow indifferent. But tell me, who laid that mean Contrivance to my charge?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You would ſhow your Reſentment of the Diſcovery, but I need not tell you.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p:
Nay then, I am convinc'd this is a meer Pretence for leaving me. 'Tis kind however to leſſen my Sorrow for ſo •• n •• ble a Separation by ill uſage. Well, Madam, I am yet too much diſorder'd to have power to expoſtulate
poſtulate with you: Farewell. Be as happy as you make wretched; I've nothing now to court but an honourable Death.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Stay, my Lord, let's reaſon a little more calmly of this buſineſs.

div.stage: Enter Gaymood ſinging, Railmore, and Plot.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ah! give me more, give me more, &c. Heyday! Gravity has doubled her Guards here to day! O'my word they both look as ſullen as a new-married Couple, that find they've cheated one-another.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Perhaps they find they've done ſo without marrying.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: What, ſtill ſighing, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Still ſighing, becauſe ſtill unhappy.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And ſtill unhappy, becauſe ſtill in Love.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Gad, if I were in your place, I'd no longer be in Love, that I might no longer be unhappy.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Thoſe that are in Love, and blame others for loving, are like thoſe who are in Health, that blame others for being Sick.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Well, well, have a little Patience, we have been plotting that you may be quickly cur'd.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: How! perhaps then you may know ſomething of a Sham Letter! ſay, do you? Nay, quickly tell me, I'm all Impatience.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, perhaps we do, perhaps we don't; I won't tell you.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: But the Lady accuſes me of ſhowing.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
Pſha, Pſha, ſhowing is neceſſary ſometimes; the Lady is a Fool, My Lord: keep your Breath for her; go, get you gone together, be addreſſing and redreſſing, preſſing and careſſing, trying and denying, flying and lying,
cooing and ſhewing; but firſt be you going, that we may be doing.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: But my Innocence—

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Shall appear as white as Curds and Cream in nine and twenty minutes. The Grove is a pretty place for cooing Lovers; wou'd you had the Wit to make uſe on't ſo long.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: But———

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Lord, will you ne'r ha' done? I hate a man that makes ſo many words.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Well, Plot, are all things ready?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but I fear your Tom will ſcarce be taken for Mrs. Francelia, tho' the Squire's as dull and credulous as a London Mob: If you could but get one of the Maids to paſs for her in the dark, my Comrade can marry 'em by Rote, as well as the beſt Hedge-Parſon between Marybone and Dukes-Place: The Rogue has ſuch a mind to be married, that none can have the Form by Heart better than he; no, not a Maid of eight and twenty, nor a Widow of three Husbands.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What ſhall we do? Ilbred and his Uncle will be here preſently, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
Catſo! we wanted ſome body to fit a Squire, and who ſhould come in the nick but a Chambermaid! Leave me to manage her: Away. Exit Railm.
Plot, liſten you Dog, and come in when you judge 'tis time.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, we Waitingmen need not be bid to liſten, we do it as naturally as Drawers, Landladies, Chambermaids, or Informers.

div.stage: Plot goes and peeps by the Door.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: How now, my skittiſh piece of Chamber-ſtuff, have I caught you at laſt?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pray Sir, let me alone.

div.stage: he holds her by the Arm.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: To Morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: I vow and proteſt Sir, I'll call.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Let it be ſo ſoftly then, that no body may hear thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Let me go Sir, what will you get by keeping me here?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Not a Maiden-head, I dare ſwear.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Come, fear not, I'll be very kind; I ſwear I love thee.

sp.speaker: Plot,
sp.p: So do I, as a Politician loves an Informer, for our own Ends.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I aſſure you Sir. I'm none of thoſe; Pſhau, let me go; are there not Citizens Wives, Masks, and other naughty Women enough?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Toaſt me, if they ben't as ſcarce of late, as honeſt Attornies. What for Sea Captains, Land Officers, and City Beaus, there's ſcarce a Wench to be had for Love or Money.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: That's a Lye, as too many can juſtify.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Have a care, thou' • t have the Green-ſickneſs; gad, I love mightily to prevent it, Child, but the Devil ſhall cure it for me. But I have another Propoſal to make to thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pray Sir, don't keep me here; I aſſure you I am honeſt.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: What will this World come to! O the Impudence of a Chamber-maid that wou'd ſcandalize her Calling!

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
Hark you, Prethee what woudſt thou be honeſt for? hah! Don't hundreds of batter'd Town Wenches get rich Husbands at laſt? Don't notorious Raſcals jump into good Places, and detected Knaves keep their old ones, or get better? Don't we ſee cheating Collectors, ſquinting Bribe-mongers, embezling Purſers, long-winded Pay-maſters, ſaggoting Officers, Brokers and Retailers of Offices
and Benefices, Pimps, Stallions, Catamites, and the Devil and all of Rogues look big, ride in Coaches, reſpected and waited on by the Croud of honeſt ſcoundrel Fools, that trudge it on the hoof? honeſt! ha, ha, hah!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well, when you can make me live like one of theſe fine Folks, perhaps I may talk to you.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: So, I knew 'twou'd come to that: Upon my honor, we poor Rogues cannot afford to be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Look you Child, I'll put you immediately in a way to do it. Thou ſhalt marry Squire Ilbred, whom thou ſaw'ſt here to day, a Man of 3000 l. a Year; Nay, and a Fool to boot. That is, provided thou' • t let me confirm him my Fool, as ſoon as Marriage has made him thine.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sure Sir, you jeſt, 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: To deny me, you mean. Look you, he loves my Neice Francelia; and we have contrived it ſo, that he believes ſhe's to marry my Lord this Evening in the dark, for fear of my Brother. The Squire is to come in my Lord's ſtead and wed her. Now you ſhall be introduced in her Place by my Lord's Man, who manages the Intrigue, and ſo ſhe'll be ſecur'd to my Friend, and the Squire to you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh! but Sir.—

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Oh! but 3000 l. a year! ſay no more, it muſt be ſo; or—Oh! here comes the Man ſhall direct you

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well, I can't avoid complying, as things ſtand; the Conſequence cannot be bad, what ever comes on't

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Plot, Here's Fanny ſhall act my Neice, and Wed Squire Ilbred; be ſure the Parſon and you whiſper all the while. As ſoon as you have done, we'll all come in and be Witneſſes But hark you, Sir Pandarus; if you offer to be familiar, take notice, I'll make a Capon of a Craven.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p:
O-law, Sir! upon my honor, I'm not ſo ill-bred
as to offer to be ſerved before my Betters: I'll immediately leave her with the Parſon.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Hah, ha, hah! I can but laugh to think how I ſhall fool both Parties with one Plot, juſt as all other Matchmakers do. The Chamber-maid ſhall fool the Squire, but I'll fool the Chamber-maid. The Jade was honeſt juſt as others are, till a good Bribe came in the way.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: What, alone, Squire?

div.stage: claps him hard on the back.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Not till you came, Knight; I was a thinking.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: That's a wonder! prethee, thinking o' what?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, only of bribing a Woman to cuckold the Fool her Husband on her Wedding Night; for I find nothing but a Bribe will do't. A Love Suite now is like a Law Suite, he that courts without Fees, ſtarves his Cauſe, and ſues in forma pauperis.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Did not you tell me once you ne're gave a Wench any thing?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: True, there's the buſineſs, I wou'd bribe her at another Man's coſt; for I love as little to f • e Wenches, as to bribe Lawyers; dam me, I hate to encourage Vice.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Well, Sam, wil't ſpeak a good word to thy Neice for honeſt Bob.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Between you and I, honeſt Bob, 'twill be needleſs; I fancy my Lord Lovewel will have her before to Morrow Noon, if he has her not by this time, and ſo I leave you.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: I find this ſame Gypſie-fellow told us true, Cuz. ſhe's to be married in hugger-mugger. I wiſh he'd come and make good his promiſe.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p:
Ods bobs, tho' ſhe frumpt me, I fancy ſhe's only ſtrange at firſt, like other Cattle; but ſhe has a ſtrange way with her, let her ſay what ſhe will, I cannot but like her. Well, I'd be content to leave off riding hard, and drinking
hard, a whole Week, ſo I might but get her in a Corner, or on a Hay-cock, and no body▪ by.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, are you come? you're too late▪

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Ods lidikins, don't tell us ſo Man: Why, 'tis not half an hour ſince I left her. O law! O law! I could weep like any Calf now.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: If 'tis done, 'tis done; come away, and drown Sorrow; thou ſhalt go home as drunk as if thou cam'ſt from an Election.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Hold, hold Sir, I did but Jeſt with you; but a Moment later had been too—Well, Mrs▪ Francelia waits for me to take her aſide, and my Lord is with her Father, diſcourſing about you and her. Come▪ now's your time, make no noiſe.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Come along, I'm as ſtill as a Mouſe.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Here my Ʋnkle deſir'd us to ſtay for him; but I can't gueſs his Deſign.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: Deſign! Why, he has as ſeldom any, as our Modern Play-Writers, unleſs it be to make us talk as he does himſelf.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: To no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: But ' • will not be my Fault, if we do not talk to the purpoſe▪ Madam. Love, Love, Madam! Nothing's to the purpoſe but that.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nay, no Love in earneſt; good Mr. Airy; don't I know you're a meer Weather-cock?

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I may be like the Weather-cock; for I never change till that which moves me changes; and all my Motions wait upon your Breath. But here▪ moſt Women are like our Weather, ſcorch us and chill us the ſame day: And others make Love ſo tedious a Plague—

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: As if there were not Plagues enough in Life, without making one of Loving; but ſome of you make as much haſte to get out of Love, as they do to get in Debt.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: I am not for running ſo faſt; for as one ſaid, going to his Wives Funeral; What need we make a Toyl of a Pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Come, come, moſt of you ſerve your Miſtreſſes as all People do their Gueſts: At firſt the Entertainment is warm and coſtly, but ſoon grows as cold as dull indifference or jaded Matrimony can make it.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: But I am for a • ove eaſie and agreeable, like your humor, and that muſt be laſting. Such a Love, Madam—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Is as indifferent a Love as one can wiſh, and in Truth, no Love at all▪

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: No, Madam, 'tis a pretty, ſociable Paſſion, like modern Friendſhip. It cheers a loving couple when together; yet is no pain to 'em when aſunder. 'Tis like Fire in a Flint, it lyes till 'tis urg'd, but then it never fails to ſparkle.

sp.speaker: C. H.
sp.p: Never Court One of our reſerv'd Beauties, Mr. Airy, ſhe wou'd expect a ſtricter Duty from her Lover.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Yes, Firſt he muſt be a Slave to Dreſs as much as ſhe is to her Complexion, and never ſee her unleſs he's as Spruce as a Dancing▪ Maſter at his breaking up, or a politick Beau on a Birth-day at Court.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Ay, for I heard of a Beau that loſt a Lady for offering to approach her in a Coat with Pocket-holes an Inch too high, and Button-holes but Three Inches wide.

div.stage: Enter Gaymood, who goes towards the Door and opens it. Sir Topew, Square Ilbred▪ and Frankly appear, and Parſon Humdrum behind 'em.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Now you ſhall have ſport.

div.stage: He ſays this, and goes towards the Door.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: To promiſe Sport, is the way to ſpoyl it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: What's he going to do?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, you muſt not Marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: No more he muſt not; he has Married her already.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Yes, Faith Unkle-in-Law that is now; you come a Day after the Fair; Here's my lawful wedded Wife, and your—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Brothers Maid, Brother-Sterling that ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You're merry diſpos'd Unkle: Why, don't you know your own Neice?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Yes, better then you know your own Bride, it ſeems: Look on her in the light.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Hah! What art thou?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Even what you ſaid juſt now, my Dear, your lawful wedded Wife.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: The Devil's rather. Ods bobs, do you take me for a Changling? I was Married to Mrs. Frances.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Nay, thy Wife's Name's Frances; She's the Changling: But my Couſin Francelia has not been in the Room this Evening.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: I'm in Amaze! Or, I Dream, or, I am Mad, or elſe I'm Drunk.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You have had my hand ever ſince the Good Man joyn'd us, and Here's the Ring.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Nay, then I'le hang my ſelf, O-law! O-law!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Oh fye, what a filthy Death you've choſen? Remember you're a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: What, cheated! There's Conjuring in't. Hah! is't ſo, thou young Witch?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Come Knight, ſpeak more kindly to your Niece; he has Married her you know, you're a Witneſs to't your ſelf.

div.stage: Enter Railmore and my Lady Single, and Plot behind'em

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What's the matter, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
Why, Mr. Ilbred has committed Matrimony with
One of the Maids, and wou'd perſwade us 'twas my Neice Francelia▪ that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: This ſhan't paſs ſo, d'you ſee.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: No, 'tis paſt already, d'you ſee: How will you help your ſelves? The Gudgeon that's caught in the hook may flounce, and flounder, but that wont do. He hugs it, and tugs it as a Man does his Wife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir Topewel, and you Mr. Ilbred, I'le ſhow you I'm not ſo much your Enemy as you Imagine: I fancy, I have One way to bring you off.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: How? ah, wou'd you cou'd▪

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: If you'l bind your ſelf in a Bond of Twenty Thouſand Pounds, never to pretend to Mrs. Fran • elia, I'le try what I can do for you.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Ay, with all my Spirit, and thank you too.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Here's a Bond ready drawn; look on it, 'tis but Signing and Sealing.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he ſhall Sign it and Seal it, and with more joy than any ever Sign'd a Contract of Marriage; here Cuz, Sign, Sign and Seal; but lets ſee if 'tis right firſt? heigh ho! how ſoon care comes upon a Man that's Married! he's no ſooner noos'd but he'd give his Ears to get off. Here 'tis Sign'd and Seal'd.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Take off the Seal; you deliver this as your Act and Deed, for the uſe of the Party therein mentioned.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: I do. Well, now, dear Friend of ours, prythee tell us quickly, how ſhall I get off? Pray put a Body out of pain!

sp.speaker: Ra
sp.p: Look you, before this Company, I declare you free to Marry any One that will have you, except Mrs Francelia: For, as we got this Maid to Perſonate her, we got alſo One of my Lord's Men to Perſonate the Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Ilb
sp.p: O-law! o-law! Is that all you had to ſay? You're good to help a lame Dog over a Stile.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Where is he? This is not the Man.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That's the Man that married me.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ods death, this is none of Dick; this is Parſon Humdrum.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Plot, Rogue, Dog, how is this? Why ſure you did not let the Gentleman Marry a Serving▪ Wench in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: As I'm an honeſt Perſon, Sir, I cou'd not help it. I had got my Comrade ready according to your directions, and told the Squire and his Unkle ſo, but they wou'd needs have a Parſon of their own, whom they had brought: I did all in▪ the World to perſwade 'em not to have him (they know it) but they were poſitive, and for fear of ſpoyling my Maſters Match, I durſt not hinder 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Rogue, Villain, Dog, let me come at him.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Nay, then, your humble Servant, tho' I know what I know 'tis time to ſcamper.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir Topewel? Mr. Ilbred what ails you?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, nothing, he wou'd have taken a Wife with nothing, and he has One with nothing; ſo there's nothing loſt: Tho' he has miſtaken your Maid for your Daughter; ſure the Maid will be kept Cheaper than the Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Not when the Maid comes to be the Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: True; an Uſurer's rakiſh Son, after his Dad's Damnation, or a half ſtarv'd Seaman after his Pay-Day, is not more Expenſive,

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well if he has Married her, let him make much of his blind Bargain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What, and is Meeſter ſped already! Wiſh your Worſhip Joy! Here's Doll Hoydon and I are Friends again, an't pleaſe you, and want but your Worſhip's Conſent to be Marry'd too.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Here's the Conſent I give you, with a Horſe-pox.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: • iey day,! What time o'th' Moon is't? What Waſp, or Nettle has ſtung him?

sp.speaker: Ga▪
sp.p: Why, thy Maſter ha • married thy Miſtreſſes Fellow-Servant thro' a miſtake, and he is mad at it.

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.p: What, yonder▪ Minx! Odſnigs, I know what I know; now could I help him at a dead lift, but I have a good mind not to do it, for the ſake of this ſame kick o' the breech he gave me.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: How! canſt thou help thy Maſter off of this ugly Job, Humphrey?

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.p: Mayhaps I can, mayhaps I won't; what then? You'd give me ſuch another Kick as you did e'en now, wou'd you?

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Prethee, good Humphrey, don't take it in dudgeon; I'd ha' done as much to mine own mother. Why man, I'm mad. Here, hit me Two Kicks for my One; pray do, pray do; do but bring me off, and kick me till thou'ſt loſt me, an'thee wou'dſt.

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.p:
Well, now you cry pectcavi▪ I'll tell you: I and Do •
was looking for Sir Thomas's Chaplain, to tell him we ſhou'd want him to give us a Caſt of his Office; when who ſhou'd we ſee▪ as Luck wou'd have it, but this ſame Laſs there in the high Topping, and a tidy Skip, a little tiny go-by-ground, not paſſin thus high. (I'm ſure▪ ſhe's no higher than a Horſe-block) with the Chaplain mumbling over them out of his book; ſo we liſten'd, and found he was making 'em as faſt as a Parſon can make Two Folks.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Pſhau, pſhau, ſure this cannot be.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Why, you'd as good tell me a Bailiff's no Knave▪ I know her Face main well; D'you think I'm like your London-Folks? tell Lies? I'll take the Bibled Oath on't, an • ſo ſhall Doll; won't you Doll?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Ay, as I'm an honeſt body, that I will

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Ah boys!

div.stage: He jumps, and plays ridiculous Tricks.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ah boys! Couſin, dance, dance, I ſay: This brings thee off, boy; and as for you, Miſtreſs Chouſe, we'll have you hang'd for marrying Two Husbands.

sp.speaker: Sir▪ Tho.
sp.p: How! is this true, Sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, what, ſhall—as I hope to be ſav'd—no—for fear—I can't tell—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You can't tell what to ſay; I find 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Look you, an't pleaſe your Worſhip▪ here's the Young Smock-fac'd Hobberdehoy ſhe had pickt out for a Cloak: I ſpy'd him now peeping in here▪ See, he's hardly big enough to go a nutting. I wonder how the man could have the conſcience to marry'em. But ſome of 'em don't value a ſtraw whom they cauſe to rue, ſo they're grees'd in the fiſt▪ Tho I fancys too, they Two had been at other ſport than Puſh pin▪ elſe he durſt not ha' don't▪

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: A beardleſs boy! Fye, a Husband without a Beard is as unſeemly as a VVife with VVhiskers.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He's very Young indeed; but ſtay—ſure▪ I ſhould know that Face▪ It muſt be my Couſin Kitty! Couſin Kitty!

sp.speaker: Air. Gr.
sp.p: Miſtreſs Kitty!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What, one Female Marry another! Do you make a Jeſt of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Ilbred.
sp.p: Pray, don't you be Miſtreſs Kitty! Pray don't, pray don't.

sp.speaker: Sir Top. and Illbred,
sp.p: O Law! all's ſpoilt again; undone, undone!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What do I hear, Mr. Illand. Is it poſſible you've Marryed my Maid for ſpight?

sp.speaker: Illbr.
sp.p: Only a little by chance▪ I thought to have made ſure of you: They have tantaliz'd me twice with the hopes of being my own man again; but that, I fear, I never ſhall while I live: Yet perhaps you being her Miſtreſs may perſwade her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, ſhe's no more my Servant, ſince you are her Lord and Maſter; but tho you ſhould never have been mine, I'm ſorry for you: E'en take her with you when you will.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: What, is ſhe whiſpering already with another man?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Nay▪ 'be not jealous, Mr. Illbred; our whiſpering cannot be ſo fatal to you, as that you had with her, and Doctor Humdrum.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis time to be gone! To be thus inſnar'd, and then fool'd over and over again with ſham promiſes of getting free is too much for Fleſh and Blood to bear. 'Owns! • 'll be reveng'd, if I live; come, come away.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Hold▪ you muſt take care of your Bride, Mr. Bridegroom, for all your huffing.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay then if the Bridegroom muſt take care of the Bride; you and Mr. Illbred muſt give me leave to take care of this pretty little Partner of mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Take care of h •• and be hang'd; the Devil a bit we'll take care of either.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Well, well, good angry red Nos'd Gentleman, we'll take care of one another.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: What, affront my Noſe; you little Snipper Snapper? Odſooks, it coſt more a Painting than all the Saffron Faces in a Play-houſe.

sp.speaker: La. An.
sp.p: How Siſter Kitty, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: No madder than your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: She's only Married▪ Madam, and to a perſon that will ſtrive to ſhow himſelf not altogether unworthy that happineſs.

sp.speaker: La. Sin.
sp.p: How! married in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Illbr.
sp.p: Unkle, mind, mind a little!

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Dear Madam, be pacified; the Chambermaid is Mr. Frankly, no more a Woman than my ſelf; but a very worthy young Gentleman, whoſe Wealth and merit intitle him to a young Lady that has both: He diſcover'd himſelf to me now, and told me he was forc'd to uſe this Diſguiſe to ſecure pretty Mrs. Kitty to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What the Chambermaid prove a man at laſt!

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Huzzah!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Huzzah, Cuz, thou'rt unmarried now: Odſooks let's go and be bloody Drunk for Joy.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Odsbobs I'm more glad now I've miſs'd the wrong, than if I had got the right.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I was inform'd your Ladiſhip wou'd not ſuffer your Siſter to entertain the leaſt thoughts of a Husband; I got admittance here as a Maid-Servant two days ago; and as you threaten'd her with a Nunnery, ſhe conſented the more eaſily to be joyn'd to me in more ſuitable Bonds.

sp.speaker: La. Sin.
sp.p: You mean Spirited wanton Girl! Did you then regard my Admonitions no better? 'Tis true, I threaten'd you with a Nunnery, but 'twas but to deter you from marriage, the more fatal Priſon of the two. See me no more.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Jeeringly. Come, Madam, we gueſs your Averſion to Marriage is ſomewhat abated, pray let your Anger be ſo too. Mr. Railmore, you'll interceed.

sp.speaker: La. Sin.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: In ſhort, we know that the ſame Spiritual Executioner that diſpatch'd us had done as much for you two juſt half an hour before: So now 'tis about an hour too late for your Ladiſhip to uſe that ſtyle.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What, my Lady Single married!

sp.speaker: Ld. Lo.
sp.p: Railmore married!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: The two marriage haters married!

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Nay, then miracles are not ceas'd!

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Why a miracle? I never heard any one rail at the Courtier's Slaviſh Life, but what would at one time or other Sacrifice his Liberty to it.

sp.speaker: La. Sin.
sp.p: The two extreams Love and Hate touch one another, like Laughing and Weeping.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: You are all Epheſian Matrons one way or other.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
What a Pox, are you capping of Sentences? Wiſh
you Joy—of a thouſand Pounds a year, Jack; for as for a Wife I know better Things than to wiſh a Friend Joy of that.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Wiſh you Joy of your Chambermaid here! Did not you ſay you had had her already, Sam? hah?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Pſhau, Pſhau, ſo I wou'd have had her, man; had ſhe been a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Couſin, ſhall I laugh at you two a little, for railing at matrimony?

sp.speaker: Ld. Lo.
sp.p: Pray ſpare 'em, Madam, they have done well▪ Their Inclinations agreed before, and conſequently will now▪ tho a much better way. But now, Madam, to Francelia ſince I hear, my Rival has oblig'd himſelf never to raiſe his Ambition to you, let me beg of you to condeſcend to make me happy. Sure, Sir Thomas will no longer be an obſtacle to this; I had his Leave to urge my ſuit to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ay, But I'm loth to part with ſo much mony at a Time that there's ſo little.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lo.
sp.p: While Sir Thomas ſeem'd diſpos'd to part with his mony, as well as with his Daughter, it would have been imprudence to have bated him the firſt. But we'll not differ about it: So, Madam, if you will but at laſt add your conſent to your Father's, I'll ask no other Treaſure but your Perſon, which is indeed too valuable to need any addition to recommend it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This ſo generous Offer, my Lord, convinces me of the reality of your Eſteem; but to make the beſt Return I can, I ſolemnly declare, That if my Father will not be pleas▪d to part with what he promis'd ſhould be one Conſideration of his parting with me to you, I will never conſent to marry while I live.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
How! Adad, tho I love money, I love Generoſity too▪ Here, my Lord, take her, ſhe▪s yours; the money I promis'd ſhall be yours too. I muſt confeſs, I was tamper▪d with, and tempted; but there are few here wou'd not have
been tempted to break their word for Ten Thouſand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Lord Lo.
sp.p: I humbly thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Wiſh you Joy▪ Squire.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Thankyou; but Joy of what?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, of being not married; o • rather, of being married, yet no Husband: I'm ſure many would be glad to be greeted thus.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: I'm ſo little afraid of being one of thoſe, Madam, that if I can be ſo happy as to prevail with you to approve of my Love, as well as I hope your Father will of my Circumſtances, I ſhall have nothing more to wiſh but to be yours for ever.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What, are you making Love in Jeſt again? To be ſerious is a Jeſt. Firſt, let us be ſure you can continue ſome time in a mind: Miſtreſſes, they ſay, are valued by moſt of you like Plays, only for being New; You hardly come to ſee 'em after the Third Day, and it muſt be an extraordinary one, or an extraordinary Favour, if you come to the Houſe Three Days after, tho your Company's wanted there never ſo much.

sp.speaker: Ai
sp.p: Oh▪ I ſhall ſtill diſcover New Beauties, Madam, and love you more and more.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Pox, you grow too ſerious on a ſudden, man; had you not better make Love in Jeſt ſtill? The very Boy and Girl in the Houſe will teach you to keep to that. Oh, here they are. —Come Sing the Dialogue my pretty Rogues!

div.head: A Dialogue between a little Boy and Girl.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I play truant to come hither,
To go with you up and down,
I'de leave all the Boys in Town.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: My dear Jemmy, how d'you do?
I'd leave all the Girls for you,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come, let's play at Man and Wife▪

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Fye, you know that's full of ſtrife.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, we'll kiſs and hug each other,
Like my Father and your Mother.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: When you're out, I'll put you in.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Pray, be not ſo ſhy, my D • ary.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Keep your distance, or I'le tear you!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: None can ſee us, do not fear.
Now a little more, good Betty.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Fye, you make me bluſh I ſwear;

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Oh! I cannot, will not tarry.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Very well▪ but I find they are ſeduced as well as the reſt, by the evil Spirit of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What, can't our Example make a Convert of you?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
No, ſaith; I ſhou'd be afraid of the Matrimonial Curſe, ••
••• without ſtomach, walk about without • aſe, ſing without • i • th, go to bed without deſire, enjoy without pleaſure, lie without Reſt, be Cuckolded without mercy, • ught at without pity, and plagu'd without end.

sp.speaker: La. Sin,
sp.p: What, will you never have better Thoughts of our Sex?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ay, when you all ceaſe to go to Prayers without Devotion, to fawn without Love, to weep without ſorrow, to be chaſte without Vertue, and to get Children without your Husbands.

div.stage: Re-enter Frankly dreſt like a Gentleman, and Kitty in her own Clothes. Plot behind 'em.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Mr. Frankly, now your Friends may know you; you're your ſelf again.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Dear Airy, help me to obtain Sir Thomas ▪s, and my Lady Single's Pardon for uſing a Stratagem that may ſeem ſomewhat inhoſpitable to thoſe who never felt the violence of Love. As for Mr. Illbred, he muſt not only forgive me, but honeſt Plot alſo, to whom I had made my ſelf known before I was to wed the Squire; ſo that there was no danger on either ſide.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p:
The ſhort and the long of the Stor •
•• that between Jeſt and Earneſt I'm fairly chous'd of my Miſtreſs among you, e faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come, come, we'll get thee another▪ Cuz.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Get thee another, Cuz! Odsbobs, 'tis all along of you▪ Gnaw, gnaw, you Old Fool: Before George, I've as good a mind as e're I had in my life, to have Suſan, Siſters Chambermaid, for ſpight.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O fie, Sir, no Chambermaid in earneſt▪ I beſeech you; come, be thankful; thoſe who take our Miſtreſſes from us, improve our Parts; firſt we love as Learners, but afterwards like Maſters.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir Topewell, let me give you ſome Counſel which ſeveral men in your ſtation ſhould follow; Allow ſome needy man of Sence a Genteel maintenance to give your Young Squire good Education by degrees. Let him read good books moderately, but chiefly the great book of the world, not to be found with Pedants. It coſts ſo little more to breed a man like a Gentleman, than it does to breed others like Clowns, that I wonder there are ſo many of the latter with good Paternal Eſtates.

lg.l: Good Education muſt our Youth improve,
And fit a man for Buſineſs and for Love.
Wealth may be loſt, but never what we gain
By reading Books, and moſt by reading Men.
Thus we grow wiſe, and raiſe and uſe our ſtore;
While Fops and Squires, amidſt their Wealth, are poor.
